slow burn horror film. There's a Japanese movie that I love called Audition, directed by Takashi Miike, who I put in a cameo in the movie as a guy coming out of this factory. And it doesn't start off scary. You know, I wanted the movie to be this journey into hell. And I wanted kind of the first act in Amsterdam with these guys paying for hookers to sort of mirror the third act in Slovakia where businessmen are paying to torture people. So I didn't want to start off all scary and gloomy with lots of blood and death, because I think that would be, you know, that gets boring after 90 minutes. And I really wanted the audience to get seduced along with the characters. I wanted them to sort of be on the journey with them. So it doesn't start off really that scary and boring. It's much more fun and get to know the guys. And then things just get worse and worse and worse and worse until it goes so much farther.

lucky enough to get to go around touring at these film festivals, and I started seeing movies that never come to America, and I was exposed to directors like Takashi Miike who did Audition and Ichi the Killer, and films coming out of South Korea like Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance, and I just thought, oh my god, what the hell is going on in these Asian countries that they are making the movies this violent? And what I saw was that American movies try to play it safe, American horror movies, they don't want to offend people, and the kind of directors like Miike understand that what makes a great horror movie is that it lives in that danger zone, that dangerous territory, and it harkens back to kind of Italian cinema in the 70s, films like Cannibal Holocaust or Pasolini's Sallow, where they're making movies that are so violent, but they're not trying to please everybody, they're not for everybody, they're for a very specific audience, they're like, this is a sick movie, if you don't like it, stay the hell away from it, and I just felt like nobody was doing anything like that in America, so that's what I wanted to do, and I also like the fact that the Asian films aren't really pure, they're not exactly the same as the Asian films, they're not exactly pure horror movies, it's not like The Garage or The Ring, there's a wave of these ultra violent films that are much more horrific than scary, you know, it's about like real people doing real things, and they're just horrifying and disturbing, and that's the type
